Comment: In the Senate, there can technically be any number of amendments proposed on a bill, and a vote can only occur once all discussion is over. The problem is that any senator can filibuster - delay a vote indefinitely by claiming that they need more time to discuss the bill. Under the current Senate rules, senators don't even need to keep talking to keep a filibuster going. Unless the senator withdraws their motion to filibuster, the only way to move on to a vote is for the majority to hold cloture - where 60+ senators vote to end discussion.  The rules of the Senate are enforced by the Senate Parliamentarian - a non-senator acting as ref. They decide whether bills are "policy" or "spending," which affects how quickly bills will pass through the process. Policy bills can be stopped from reaching a final vote by filibuster, whereas spending bills can't and get to go to a vote without cloture being needed.

Comment: Just because a bill passed the house does not mean the Senate **needs** to vote on it. That’s your first problem. They are two completely separate bodies, who communicate every now and then to function, but could theoretically exist without any discussion except for some important corner cases (budget, and when the same bill passes both chambers but w slight differences, they need to meet to talk about them, but again, don’t have to, and the bill can die again).

The Speaker will bring it to the floor like I think schedule it, I think people debate amendments to the bill, and then take a final vote. Take a cause you care about and find a significant bill that was passed on it. Go back and retrace the steps of the bill looking at the website of the steps of the bill moving through the process and looking up articles according to those dates. Comment: The House bill you're following may never get taken up in the Senate, especially since the two bodies are controlled by different parties.   In the Senate, the majority leader controls the calendar. He decides what bills get taken up when. His biggest constraint is time. Until a bill achieves cloture, there's no limit on the time available for debate. Even after cloture, rules allow 40 hours of debate before a vote, which, assuming senators want to keep talking, can mean the Senate can't do anything else until the 40 hours expire. So the majority leader often doesn't bring bills up for consideration unless the outcome of the debate and vote is predictable.
